THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Kimla C. Johnson, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26555
Heard August 20, 2008 - Filed October 20,
  2008Â Â  
INDEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Lesley
  M. Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara Seymour, Deputy Disciplinary
  Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Kimla
  C. Johnson, of Clinton, Maryland, pro se.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  This is an attorney discipline case involving misconduct
  in three matters.Â  The Commission on Lawyer Conduct Panel (Panel) unanimously recommended
  the following sanctions: (1) indefinite suspension; (2) respondent be required
  to pay the costs of the disciplinary proceedings; and (3) respondent make
  restitution to the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection (Fund) and to victims in
  the amounts set forth herein.Â  
The
  Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) appeals and argues that the facts and
  similar case law call for a harsher sanction.Â  For the reasons stated below, we
  are not persuaded that we should deviate from the Panelâ€™s recommendation.Â 
  Therefore, we impose the recommended sanctions. 

FACTS
This
  proceeding involves three separate matters.Â  An investigative panel authorized
  formal charges, which were then filed in April 2007.Â  A hearing was held before
  the Panel in October 2007 and the report of the Panel was published in April
  2008.
Respondent
  moved to South Carolina in 1990 and began practicing law in this state.Â 
  Following the birth of her second child, respondent began practicing law with
  her husband.Â  Her husband (Husband) was placed on interim suspension in August
  1999 and a number of Husbandâ€™s clients elected for respondent to take over
  their cases.
Matter A
Client
  A hired Husband to represent him in connection with an automobile collision
  that occurred in March 1999.Â  Respondent took over representation of Client A
  when Husband was placed on interim suspension.Â  In January 2000, respondent
  accepted a settlement offer on behalf of Client A in the amount of $40,000.00.Â 
  Respondent did not disburse the proceeds of $26,667.67[1] to or on behalf of Client A, but
  instead used the funds for her own benefit and for the benefit of her law
  firm.Â  
Respondent
  claimed that Client A agreed to loan the funds to her and Husband.Â  However,
  respondent failed to produce any documentation proving the existence of the
  loan and the Panel found respondentâ€™s testimony in this regard lacking in
  credibility.Â  The findings of the Panel are entitled to great weight, particularly
  when the inferences drawn from the testimony in the record depend largely on
  the credibility of witnesses. In re Yarborough, 327 S.C. 161, 165, 488
  S.E.2d 871, 873 (1997).Â  Respondent stated to ODC that her financial records
  were destroyed, but testified at the hearing that this was not true.
ODC
  presented evidence that respondent allowed Husband to communicate with Client A
  regarding settlement negotiations, and that respondent communicated with
  Husband about demand figures.
Matter B
In
  November 1999, Client B hired respondent to represent her on a contingency
  basis in connection with claims arising out of an automobile collision.Â 
  Respondent received settlement proceeds of $10,000.00 but did not place the
  proceeds in her client trust account.Â  Respondent and Client B signed a
  settlement disbursement statement which provided that respondent would receive
  attorneyâ€™s fees and pay Client Bâ€™s medical providers from the proceeds.Â  The
  remainder of the proceeds were to be paid to Client B.Â  Respondent paid some of
  Client Bâ€™s medical bills and disbursed additional proceeds to Client B, yet $1,925.67
  of the settlement funds designated to pay medical providers was neither paid to
  providers nor disbursed to Client B.[2]Â  
Matter C
In
  1999, Client C hired respondent to represent her in an employment
  discrimination matter on a contingency basis.Â  Respondentâ€™s fee arrangement was
  one-third of the recovery to increase to forty percent in the event that a
  lawsuit was filed.Â  Disciplinary Counsel produced documents showing that in
  June 2000, respondent settled Client Câ€™s claim for $122,020.76.Â  Respondent did
  not disburse the funds to Client C and instead misappropriated at least
  $75,822.18.[3]Â  
Client
  C testified that she communicated primarily with Husband about the settlement.Â 
  For a number of years, Client C contacted Husband numerous times to inquire
  about her settlement and, in response, he sent small amounts of cash to Client
  C by way of Western Union.Â  ODC presented documents showing that between
  September 2001 and December 2006, Client C received approximately $5,525.00 by
  wire from Husband.Â  
PANEL FINDINGS
With
  regard to all matters, the Panel found by clear and convincing evidence that
  Johnson violated several South Carolina Appellate Court Rules (SCACR); Rules of
  Professional Conduct (RPC), Rule 407 SCACR; and Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary
  Enforcement (RLDE), Rule 413 SCACR.Â  The Panel found violations of Rule 417,
  SCACR, failure to maintain appropriate financial records, and the following RPC:
  (1) Rule 1.4, failing to reasonably communicate with client; (2) Rule 1.8,
  entering into a business transaction with a client without documentation; (3)
  Rule 1.15, commingling of lawyer and client funds; (4) Rule 5.5, assisting in
  the unauthorized practice of law; (5) Rule 8.1, false statement in connection
  with a disciplinary matter; (6) Rule 8.4(b), committing a criminal act that
  reflects adversely on a lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness, or fitness as a
  lawyer; (7) Rule 8.4(d), engaging in conduct involving dishonesty, deceit, and
  misrepresentation; and (8) Rule 8.4(e), engaging in conduct prejudicial to the
  administration of justice. 
DISCUSSION
This
  Court has the ultimate authority to discipline attorneys and the manner in
  which the discipline is given rests entirely with this Court. In re Long,
  346 S.C. 110, 112, 551 S.E.2d 586, 587 (2001).Â  This Court may make its own
  findings of fact and conclusions of law, and is not bound by the Panelâ€™s
  recommendation. In re Larkin, 336 S.C. 366, 371, 520 S.E.2d 804, 806-07
  (1999).Â  An attorney disciplinary violation must be proven by clear and
  convincing evidence. Id.
As
  to Matter A, we do not agree with two of
  the Panelâ€™s findings.Â  First, though the Panel found that respondent did not
  loan funds to Client A, the Panel cited a breach of Rule 1.8(a), entering into
  a business transaction with a client without proper documentation.Â  If no loan
  existed, then respondent cannot have violated this rule.Â  Second, we find that
  ODC failed to prove by clear and convincing evidence that respondent assisted
  with the unauthorized practice of law.Â  The Panel notes that respondent
  communicated with Husband regarding demand figures after the date of his
  interim suspension.Â  As Husband was the original attorney in the matter,
  respondentâ€™s communication with Husband concerning the status of the case does
  not constitute assisting with the unauthorized practice of law. 
With
  regard to Matter C, we find that ODC failed to prove by clear and convincing
  evidence that respondent assisted with the unauthorized practice of law.Â  ODC
  alleged and the Panel found only that Husband communicated with Client C
  regarding her case and sent funds by way of Western Union.Â  While such actions
  may constitute the unauthorized practice of law by Husband, no evidence was
  presented to show that respondent assisted Husband in his actions. 
In
  mitigation of the remaining violations, we note that respondentâ€™s mother died
  tragically and unexpectedly in 1999 as respondent was administering CPR.Â 
  Respondent testified that her motherâ€™s death caused her to feel great grief and
  guilt, which persisted well after the event and contributed to her
  decision-making.Â  Also in 1999, shortly after the death of her mother, Husband
  was placed on interim suspension from the practice of law. Â Respondent found
  herself solely responsible for their law practice and responsible for having to
  provide for her two special needs children.Â  Respondent testified that the
  period of time in which the two events occurred constituted a very traumatic
  time in her life.Â  Her misconduct occurred close in time to these events.Â  
CONCLUSION
The
  unanimous findings and conclusions of the Panel are entitled to much respect
  and consideration. Larkin, supra, at 371, 520 S.E.2d at 806. Â Based
  on the facts and mitigating factors, we are not persuaded that a harsher
  sanction is warranted in this case.Â  We therefore adopt the Panelâ€™s
  recommendation and indefinitely suspend respondent from the practice of law.Â  
With
  regard to restitution, we agree with the Panel that Client A is entitled to
  restitution in the amount of $26,667.67 and Client B is entitled to restitution
  in the amount of $1,925.67.Â  However, we note that the Panelâ€™s recommendation
  as to Client C does not comport with the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection
  Rules of Procedure. [4]Â 
  Section IV of the Rules of Procedure states that before a client may be
  reimbursed by the Fund, the client must sign a subrogation agreement.Â  The
  Rules also set forth the following procedure if the client later recovers from
  the offending attorney: â€œAny amounts recovered . . . by the client, in excess
  of the amount to which the Fund is subrogated . . . shall be paid to or
  retained by the client as the case may be.â€ Id.Â  We therefore order
  respondent to make restitution to all injured parties, including clients and
  the Fund.Â  We emphasize that Client C shall not receive funds from respondent
  in restitution until the Fund is fully reimbursed for the $40,000.00 already
  paid to Client C from the Fund.Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel shall implement
  a plan for restitution and payment of costs within thirty days of this opinion.
In
  summary, respondent must meet the following requirements before she may be
  re-admitted to the practice of law: (1) satisfy Rule 33(f), RLDE, Rule 413,
  SCACR; (2) pay costs of the disciplinary proceedings in accordance with the
  plan to be set forth by ODC; and (3) make restitution in accordance with the
  plan to be set forth by ODC.
Respondent
  shall file, within fifteen days of this opinion, an affidavit with the Clerk of
  Court stating that she has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR and shall
  also surrender her Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk
  of Court. 
INDEFINITE
  SUSPENSION.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Client Aâ€™s net proceeds after attorneyâ€™s fees.
[2] The Panel arrived at this figure by subtracting the
  following amounts from the $10,000 settlement proceeds: an attorneyâ€™s fee in
  the amount of $3,333.33, a payment by respondent to one of the providers in the
  amount of $2,357.00, and payments to Client B in the amounts of $1,900.00 and
  $484.00.
[3] The Panel arrived at this figure by subtracting from
  the proceeds of approximately $122,000 a one-third contingency fee and the
  total amount of funds sent by way of Western Union by Husband to Client C in
  response to her inquiries about the settlement.Â  
[4] Client C has already received $40,000.00 from the
  Fund, the maximum available to an individual.Â  In an effort to fully compensate
  Client C, the Panel ordered respondent to repay $40,000.00 to the Fund and to
  pay an additional $35,822.18 to Client C.Â  While we appreciate the Panelâ€™s
  intent, where a client has received money from the Fund, the Fund must be
  repaid before the client can receive any additional restitution from the
  attorney. See Section IV, Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection Rules of
  Procedure.Â

PER CURIAM:Â Â 
  In contemplation of filing a Petition for Reinstatement, respondent discovered
  a scrivenerâ€™s error in the Courtâ€™s original opinion in this matter.Â  The Court
  reissues its opinion as follows. Â Â 
In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of
  Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by
  Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement,
  respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of any sanction set
  forth in Rule 7(b), RLDE.Â  Respondent
  requests that if a suspension is imposed, it be made retroactive to the date of
  her interim suspension. Â See In the Matter of Farlow, 369 S.C. 48,
  631 S.E.2d 75 (2006).Â  We
  accept the agreement and find a two year suspension from the practice of law is
  the appropriate sanction.Â  The
  suspension shall not be made retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim
  suspension.Â  
FACTS
The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.Â 
  Respondent pled guilty to one count of accommodation distribution of marijuana
  without remuneration, in violation of 21 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 841(b)(1)(D) and 841(b)(4),
  and one count of possession of methylenedioxymethamphetamine hydrochloride,
  also known as â€œecstasy,â€ in violation of 21 U.S.C. Â§ 844(a).Â  Respondent was
  sentenced to six monthsâ€™ imprisonment on each count, to be served concurrently.[1]Â  It was also ordered that, upon
  release, respondent be under supervision for one year, six months of which must
  include participation in the home confinement program with electronic
  monitoring.
LAW
Respondent admits that, by her misconduct, she has
  violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule
  407, SCACR:Â  Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage
  in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation) and Rule
  8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is
  prejudicial to the administration of justice).Â  Respondent also admits her misconduct
  constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for
  discipline for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct) and Rule
  7(a)(5) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to engage in conduct
  tending to pollute the administration of justice, to bring the courts or legal
  profession into disrepute, or demonstrate an unfitness to practice law) of the
Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR.

CONCLUSION
We accept
  the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and suspend respondent from the
  practice of law in this state for two years.Â  The suspension shall not be made retroactive to the date of
  respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  Within
  fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an
  affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that she has complied with Rule 30 of
  Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender her Certificate of Admission to the
  Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.Â  In addition, as set forth in the
  agreement, respondent shall, within thirty (30) days of the date of this
  opinion, pay $861.88 for costs incurred in the investigation and prosecution of
  this matter by the Office of Disciplinary Counsel and the Commission on Lawyer
  Conduct.
DEFINITE
  SUSPENSION.
TOAL,
C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  



[1] At the sentencing hearing, it was also determined
  respondent had given perjured testimony in the trial of another individual.Â 
  The acts that gave rise to both the criminal charges against respondent and the
  finding of perjury occurred prior to respondentâ€™s admission to the practice of
law.

description: This is an opinion in which the Court imposed reciprocal discipline on a lawyer.

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Blaine T. Edwards, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26556
Submitted September 29, 2008 - Filed October 27, 2008Â Â Â  

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
        Lesley M.
          Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Joseph P. Turner, Jr., Assistant
          Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        Blaine T.
          Edwards, of Greenville, pro se.Â  
      
    
  

PER
  CURIAM:Â  This attorney disciplinary matter
  is before the Court pursuant to the reciprocal disciplinary provisions of Rule
  29, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  
FACTS
Respondent is licensed to practice law in
  South Carolina, the United States District Court for the District of South
  Carolina (USDC), and the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of
  South Carolina (Bankruptcy Court).Â  On August 16, 2006, the Court placed
  respondent on interim suspension.Â  In the Matter of Edwards, 370 S.C.
  74, 634 S.E.2d 645 (2006).Â  As a result of his interim suspension, the USDC
  automatically suspended respondent on August 29, 2006.Â  See Local Rule
  83.I.08 (D.S.C. (RDE Rule II(G)) (â€œIf an attorney admitted to practice before
  [the USDC] is disbarred or suspended by the Supreme Court of South Carolina,
  [the USDC] shall immediately order the identical disciplinary actionsâ€¦.â€).Â  On
  September 20, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court suspended respondent as a consequence
  of his suspension before the USDC.Â  See Local Rule 83.IX.02 (â€œPursuant
  to Bankruptcy Rule 9029m the Bankruptcy Judges of this District are hereby
  authorized to make such rules of practice and procedure as they may deem
  appropriate; provided, however, that in promulgating the rules governing the
  admission or eligibility to practice in the Bankruptcy Court, the Bankruptcy
  Judges shall require District Court admission â€¦.â€). 
In the meantime, in connection with
  actions filed by Gary and Dana Henderson and James and Kathryn Henson, the
  Bankruptcy Court had issued an order requiring respondent to appear to explain
  his failure to provide competent and diligent representation to the Hendersons
  and the Hensons, to show cause why his fees should not be disgorged, and to
  show cause why further sanctions should not be imposed including, but not
  limited to, suspension from practice before the Bankruptcy Court and/or
  disgorgement of fees in other cases.Â  See Bankruptcy Court order dated
  August 25, 2006.Â  
Respondent appeared before the Bankruptcy
  Court onÂ  August 31, 2006 hearing.Â  By order dated September 5, 2006, the Bankruptcy
  Court found respondent had failed to file documents by the required deadlines
  which resulted in the dismissal of the Hendersonsâ€™ and Hensonsâ€™ bankruptcy
  petitions and ordered respondent to disgorge his attorneyâ€™s fees within five
  (5) days.Â  The judge continued the Rule to Show Cause hearing to consider other
  sanctions until September 21, 2006.Â  
Respondent did not appear at the Rule to
  Show Cause hearing.Â  On October 4, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court issued an order
  again requiring respondent to disgorge the balance of fees received from the
  Hendersons and Hensons within ten (10) days.[1]Â 
  In particular, the court noted:Â  

  [i]nasmuch as [respondent] is
    presently suspended from practice before this [Bankruptcy] Court, as a
    consequence of the [August 29, 2006 USDC] suspension, the [Bankruptcy] Court
    need not take further immediate action regarding his ability to currently
    practice in this [Bankruptcy] Court, except that [respondentâ€™s] suspension
      from practice before this [Bankruptcy] Court shall continue, regardless of
      reinstatement by the [USDC], until further order of this [Bankruptcy] Courtâ€¦Reinstatement
    to practice before this [Bankruptcy] Court may be conditioned upon his
    compliance with orders of this [Bankruptcy] Court and such other conditions as
    this [Bankruptcy] Court may impose. 

(Underline added).Â  
The Bankruptcy Court
  continued the first Rule to Show Cause hearing and issued a second Rule to Show
  Cause order directing respondent to appear on October 19, 2006 â€œto show cause
  why further sanctions should not be imposed or limits placed on his ability to
  gain reinstatement to practice before this [Bankruptcy] Court based upon his
  representation of [the Hendersons and Hensons] in these cases and in all
    other cases filed in this [Bankruptcy] Court in which he failed to file
    documents on behalf of his clients.â€Â Â Â  
(Underline added).Â  
Respondent appeared for the show cause
  hearings on October 19, 2006.Â  The Bankruptcy Courtâ€™s October 24, 2006 order
  provides:Â  

  [t]he [Bankruptcy] Court orders
    that [respondent] shall be suspended from practice before this [Bankruptcy] Court,
    notwithstanding any intervening reinstatement by other courts within this
    District, until such time as [respondent] brings a motion for reinstatement to
    practiceâ€¦.The motion for reinstatement shall be heard by the undersigned as
    Chief Bankruptcy Judge for this District who may place conditions and
    limitations on [respondentâ€™s] ability to be reinstated to practice before this [Bankruptcy]
    Court, including, but not limited to [respondent] complying with the orders
    of this [Bankruptcy] Court disgorging his attorneyâ€™s fees to his clients,
    [respondent] demonstrating that he is able to provide competent and diligent
    representation to clients, and [respondent] attending continuing legal
    education classes in the area of ethics and bankruptcy.[2] 

(Underline added).Â  
The Bankruptcy Court
  amended its October 4, 2006 order to reflect the additional conditions
  regarding respondentâ€™s suspension before the court.Â  It dissolved the two Rules
  to Show Cause, but stated the orders concerning disgorgement of fees remained
  in effect.Â  
On June 9, 2008, ODC filed a certified
  copy of the Bankruptcy Courtâ€™s January 4, 2007 Supplemental Order in In re
    Storay.Â  In that order, the Bankruptcy Court discussed respondentâ€™s failure
  to pursue thirty (30) bankruptcy petitions, the resulting dismissal of
  twenty-four (24) of the cases, respondentâ€™s concession that he had no funds to
  repay the twenty-four (24) clientsâ€™ retainers, and his agreement that he should
  be required to repay the twenty-four (24) clients, with interest, before
  reinstatement by the Bankruptcy Court.Â  The Bankruptcy Courtâ€™s order provides: 

  It is therefore ordered that [respondent]
    shall repay to the debtors in the 24 cases which were dismissed as a result of
    his failure to file schedules and statements all of the fees, including filing
    fees, paid to him by the debtors in those cases.Â  [Respondent] shall also pay
    interest on those fees from October 16, 2005, until the date of repayment at
    the rate of eight and one-half percent per annum.Â  In the event that
    [respondent] seeks reinstatement to practice before this [Bankruptcy] Court, he
    shall first be required to produce satisfactory proof of payment of the fees
    ordered to be repaid herein.Â  [Respondent] shall also provide twenty-day (20)
    written, advance notice to the debtors in the 24 dismissed cases of any
    application seeking reinstatement to practice before this [Bankruptcy] Court so that the debtors may have the opportunity to be heard on the merits of the
    application.Â  This Order supplements the terms in conditions regarding
    [respondentâ€™s] ability to gain reinstatement to practice before this [Bankruptcy]
    Court as set forth in In re Henderson, C/A/ No. 05-14925-W, slip or. (Bankr.
    D.S.C. Oct. 24, 2006).[3]Â Â  

Bankruptcy Court Supplemental Order dated January 4, 2007.Â  
Pursuant to Rule 29(b), RLDE, the Clerk
  provided the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent with thirty
  (30) days in which to inform the Court of any reason why the imposition of
  identical discipline was not warranted.Â  ODC filed a response stating the
  Bankruptcy Courtâ€™s suspension was equivalent to a definite suspension of up to
  two years under Rule 7(b), RLDE, and, further, that it had no information to
  indicate that the issuance of the same discipline by the Court would not be
  warranted. Â Respondent filed a response stating that Rule 29 is inapplicable
  because reciprocal discipline only applies when discipline has been issued by a
  court physically located outside of South Carolina. 
LAW
Rule 29(a), RLDE, provides that â€œ[u]pon
  notification from any source that a lawyer within the jurisdiction of the
  Commission [on Lawyer Conduct] has been disciplined â€¦in another jurisdiction,
  disciplinary counsel shall obtain a certified copy of the disciplinary order
  and file it with â€¦the Supreme Court.â€Â  After receipt of the certified order
  â€œdemonstrating that a lawyer admitted to practice in this state has been
  disciplinedâ€¦in another jurisdiction,â€ the Court is required to issue a notice
  to the lawyer and ODC seeking a response concerning whether identical
  discipline is warranted.Â  Rule 29(b), RLDE.
Rule 29(d), RLDE, further provides that,
  after the expiration of the time for a response, the Court shall impose
  identical discipline unless the attorney or ODC demonstrate or the Court finds
  that â€œit clearly appears upon the face of the record from which the discipline
  is predicatedâ€ that the identical discipline is improper for one of several
  stated reasons including:Â  1) the procedure was so lacking in notice or
  opportunity to be heard as to constitute a deprivation of due process; 2)
  infirmity of proof of the misconduct; 3) imposition of the same discipline by
  the Court would result in grave injustice; 4) the established misconduct
  warrants substantially different discipline in this state; and 5) the reason
  for the original transfer to incapacity inactive status no longer exists.Â Â Â  
Rule 29, RLDE, authorizes this Court to
  impose reciprocal discipline on a lawyer who was disciplined â€œin another
  jurisdiction.â€Â  Contrary to respondentâ€™s assertion, Rule 29 does not require
  that the other jurisdiction be located outside the borders of this State in
  order for its provisions to apply.Â  Moreover, on at least one occasion, the
  Court has imposed reciprocal discipline on a lawyer who was sanctioned by the
  same Bankruptcy Court which disciplined respondent in the instant matter.Â  In
    the Matter of Hood, 367 S.C. 29, 625 S.E.2d 210 (2006).Â  
In summary, the Bankruptcy Courtâ€™s orders:Â 
  1) directed that respondent remain suspended, regardless of his reinstatement
  by the USDC and 2) ordered him to repay all of the fees, including filing fees,
  (plus interest) paid by the twenty-four (24) bankruptcy clients.Â  See October 24, 2006 Bankruptcy Court order and January 4, 2007 Bankruptcy Court
  order.Â  The orders further required that, if respondent seeks reinstatement, he
  must 1) provide proof of restitution to the twenty-four (24) clients, 2)
  provide twenty (20) days advance notice of his application to seek
  reinstatement, and 3) appear before the Chief Bankruptcy Judge.Â  See October 24, 2006 and January 4, 2007 Bankruptcy Court orders.Â Â Â  
We find that the sanction imposed by the
  Bankruptcy Court is most similar to a two (2) year definite suspension with the
  requirement of repayment of unearned attorneyâ€™s fees or costs under the RLDE.Â  See Rules 7(b) (sanctions) and 33 RLDE (provisions regarding reinstatement
  following definite suspension from nine months to two years). Â Further, we find
  that the same sanction is proper as reciprocal
  discipline in this matter. Â See generally In the Matter of
    Drayton, 359 S.C. 138, 597 S.E.2d 791 (2004) (indefinite suspension
  appropriate where lawyer failed to refund unearned fee to bankruptcy client,
  failed to timely withdraw from representation of clients in bankruptcy court,
  and committed other misconduct); In the Matter of Gaines, 348 S.C. 208,
  559 S.E.2d 577 (2002) (Court noted two year suspension would be appropriate for
  lawyerâ€™s lack of diligence in client matters and submission of improper
  documents to courts, among other misconduct, but disbarred lawyer due to his previous
  disciplinary history); In the Matter of Strait, 343 S.C. 312, 540 S.E.2d
  460 (2000) (six month and one day suspension appropriate for lawyerâ€™s failure
  to diligently represent two domestic clients and failure to submit paperwork
  for bankruptcy client, resulting in dismissal of case, among other misconduct); In the Matter of Jones, 340 S.C. 388, 532 S.E.2d 281 (2000) (thirty day
  suspension appropriate where lawyer failed to enter responsive pleading
  resulting in default judgment and committed other misconduct).Â  Accordingly, we hereby suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state for two
  (2) years, retroactive to August 16, 2006, the date of his interim suspension.Â  In the Matter of Edwards, supra.Â  In addition, respondent shall
  repay the twenty-four bankruptcy clients as ordered by the Bankruptcy Courtâ€™s
  orders.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file
  an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30,
  RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY
and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1]Respondent had repaid a portion of the fees to the
Henderson and Hensons. 
[2] The order specifies that respondent agreed to
the terms of the order.Â  
[3]Â  The August 25, 2006, September 5, 2006, October
  4, 2006, October 24, 2006, and January 1, 2007 Bankruptcy Court orders were
issued by John E. Waites, Chief Bankruptcy Judge for the USDC.

description: In this case, the Court reverses the decision of the court of appeals upholding the trial courtâ€™s denial of Petitionerâ€™s Batson motion.  Specifically, the Court holds that trial counselâ€™s reason for dismissing a juror was not a race-neutral reason.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Lakefhia
          McCrea, Petitioner,
        v.
        Jafer
          Gheraibeh, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS 

Appeal from Florence County
  Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No. 26557
  Heard May 29, 2008 - Filed October 27,
2008Â Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Edward
          L. Graham, of Graham Law Firm, of Florence, for Petitioner.
        C.
          Anthony Harris, Jr., of Harris McLeod & Ruffner, of Cheraw, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this case, the trial court denied Petitionerâ€™s Batson motion finding that Respondentâ€™s counselâ€™s exercise of a
  peremptory strike based on a jurorâ€™s display of dreadlocks was not racially
  motivated.Â  The court of appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision and this
  Court granted certiorari.Â  We reverse the
  decision of the court of appeals upholding the denial of Petitionerâ€™s Batson motion and remand the case for a new trial.Â  Â  Â 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
BACKGROUND
Petitioner Lakhefia McCrea brought suit seeking
  compensation for bodily injuries and vehicular damage sustained in an
  automobile accident in which Respondent Jafer
  Gheraibeh was the at-fault driver.Â  Following
  Respondentâ€™s strike of three of six potential African-American jurors during
  jury selection, Petitioner moved for a hearing pursuant to Batson v.
    Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986), arguing that Respondentâ€™s strikes of the
  African-American jurors were racially motivated and therefore impermissible.Â  
At
  the Batson hearing, the trial court asked Respondent his reason for
  striking a particular African-American juror.Â  Respondentâ€™s counsel explained:

  Your Honor, I had some uneasiness about [this particular juror].Â 
    He was - I of course have to look at jurors in light of how I think theyâ€™re
    going to judge my client as well.Â  I had some uneasiness about him.Â  I donâ€™t
    know if Your Honor recalls or not.Â  He has - heâ€™s about the only member of the
    jury I see out there with very long dreadlocks.Â  That gave me some concern in
    light of how he may react toward my client.Â  It was - as Your Honor knows,
    sometimes in selecting a juror thereâ€™s a sense or - or in deciding whether or
    not to strike someone thereâ€™s necessarily a sense of a feel about a juror and -
    and that gave me some pause . . . was his appearance including - including the
    dreadlocks.

After
  hearing counselâ€™s explanation for striking the other two African-American
  jurors, Petitioner indicated that her main concern was the strike of the juror
  with dreadlocks.[1]Â 
  Specifically, Petitioner argued that Respondentâ€™s counselâ€™s â€œuneasinessâ€ over the
  display of dreadlocks was not a sufficient basis to exercise a discretionary strike,
  and that when considered along with Respondentâ€™s strike of two other
  African-American jurors, counselâ€™s â€œuneasinessâ€ over the jurorâ€™s dreadlocks amounted
  to pretext.Â  
The
  trial judge explained that in ruling on Petitionerâ€™s Batson motion, he
  had to evaluate the credibility of the attorneys.Â  Stating that he knew both of
  the attorneys and was aware of their reputations in the community, the trial
  judge concluded that while some attorneys he knew might be inclined to exercise
  a racially-motivated jury strike, he did not believe that Respondentâ€™s attorney
  would engage in such conduct.
The jury returned a verdict in favor of Petitioner for $5,985 in
  personal injury damages and $5,000 in property damages.Â  The trial court denied
  Petitionerâ€™s post-trial motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict, a new
  trial absolute, and a new trial nisi additur, and entered judgment on Petitionerâ€™s
  behalf for $6,887.25 after reducing the verdict amount by $4,097.75 for the
  amount Respondent had previously paid.Â  
Petitioner appealed on multiple grounds and the court of appeals
  affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â  McCrea v. Gheraibeh, Op. No.
  2006-UP-072 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Feb. 2, 2006).Â  Regarding the trial courtâ€™s
  denial of Petitionerâ€™s Batson motion, the court of appeals held that counselâ€™s
  concern regarding the jurorâ€™s appearance and his dreadlocks was a
  racially-neutral explanation for the strike.Â  Id.Â  The court further reasoned
  that the decision to wear an alternative hairstyle is not specific to any race,
  and therefore, no discriminatory intent was inherent in counselâ€™s explanation.Â  Id.
This Court granted certiorari to review the decision of the court
  of appeals and Petitioner raises the following issue for review:

  Â Did the court of appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s
    denial of Petitionerâ€™s Batson motion?

LAW/ANALYSIS
Petitioner
  argues that the trial court erred in denying her Batson motion because Respondentâ€™s
  peremptory strike of a juror for wearing dreadlocks was racially motivated.Â  We
  agree.
 The Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth
  Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits the striking of a venire
  person on the basis of race or gender.Â  State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 604,
  615, 545 S.E.2d 805, 810 (2001).Â  Following the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s
  decision in Purkett v. Elem, 514 U.S. 765 (1995), this Court clarified
  the three-step method for executing a Batson hearing in State v.
    Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996).Â  Under the method articulated
  in Adams, a trial court must hold a Batson hearing when
  members of a cognizable racial group or gender are struck and the opposing
  party requests a hearing.Â  322 S.C. at 124, 470 S.E.2d at 372.Â  At the hearing,
  the proponent of the strike must offer a facially race-neutral explanation for
  the strike.Â  Then, in a final step, the burden shifts to the party challenging
  the strike to show that the explanation is mere pretext.Â  Id.Â  
In
  modifying this Courtâ€™s previous brand of Batson analysis, Adams emphasized the lack of any requirement for counsel to present a
  reasonably specific, legitimate explanation for making the strike in the second
  step of the analysis.Â  Id. at 123, 470 S.E.2d at 371.Â  Rather,
  following the lead of Purkett, this Court declared that the second step
  of a Batson inquiry only required that counselâ€™s explanation be
  race-neutral in order to ensure that the burden of showing purposeful
  discrimination remains at all times on the opponent of the strike.Â  Id. at 124, 470 S.E.2d at 372.Â  
While
  we recognize the importance of properly allocating the burden of proof in a Batson inquiry, in our view, counselâ€™s explanation that he struck the particular
  juror based simply on counselâ€™s â€œuneasinessâ€ over the jurorâ€™s dreadlocks was
  not a race-neutral reason for exercising a peremptory strike.Â  Regardless of
  their gradual infiltration into mainstream American society, dreadlocks retain
  their roots as a religious and social symbol of historically black cultures.[2]Â 
  For this reason, we hold that counselâ€™s explanation that the jurorâ€™s dreadlocks
  caused him â€œuneasinessâ€ was insufficient to satisfy the race-neutral
  requirement in the second step of the trial courtâ€™s Batson analysis.Â  See
    also Payton v. Kearse, 329 S.C. 51, 56, 495 S.E.2d 205, 208 (1998) (holding
  that basing a peremptory strike on a characterization of the juror as a
  â€œredneckâ€ is facially discriminatory in violation of Batson).Â  
By
  proceeding with a pretext inquiry under Batson without first eliciting a
  race-neutral reason for the strike from Respondentâ€™s counsel, and ultimately
  dismissing Petitionerâ€™s Batson motion based solely on the reputation of
  counsel making the strike, we find that the trial court bypassed an evidentiary
  requirement that goes to the very heart of a Batson inquiry.[3]Â 
For this reason, we hold that the trial court erred in denying Petitionerâ€™s Batson motion. 

CONCLUSION 
For
  the foregoing reasons, we reverse the decision of the court of appeals
  affirming the trial courtâ€™s denial of Petitionerâ€™s Batson motion and
  remand the case for a new trial.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
BEATTY,
  J., and Acting Justice J. Michelle Childs, concur. MOORE, J., dissenting in a
separate opinion in which PLEICONES, J., concurs.

JUSTICE
  MOORE:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I would affirm the trial
  courtâ€™s ruling that petitioner failed to meet her burden of showing that trial
  counselâ€™s reason for striking the juror was pretextual.
The Equal
  Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution prohibits the
  striking of a venire person on the basis of race or gender.Â  State v. Evins,
  373 S.C. 404, 645 S.E.2d 904 (2001), cert. denied, 128 S.Ct. 662
  (2007).Â  The proper procedure for a Batson hearing is set forth in Evins,
  at 415, 645 S.E.2d at 909.Â  After a party objects to a jury strike, the
  proponent of the strike must offer a facially race-neutral explanation.Â  Id.Â  Once the proponent states a reason that is race-neutral, the burden is on the
  party challenging the strike to show the explanation is mere pretext, either by
  showing similarly situated members of another race were seated on the jury or
  that the reason given for the strike is so fundamentally implausible as to
  constitute mere pretext despite a lack of disparate treatment.Â  Id.Â  The burden of persuading the court that a Batson violation has occurred
  remains at all times on the opponent of the strike.Â  Id.Â  
Whether a Batson violation has occurred must be determined by examining the totality of the
  facts and circumstances in the record.Â  State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 604,
  615, 545 S.E.2d 805, 810 (2001), cert. denied, 534 U.S. 977 (2001).Â 
  Typically, the decisive question is whether the attorneyâ€™s race-neutral
  explanation for a peremptory challenge should be believed.Â  Evins, at
  415-416, 645 S.E.2d at 909.Â  There is seldom much evidence in the record
  bearing on the issue, and the trial courtâ€™s findings regarding purposeful
  discrimination necessarily will rest largely on the evaluation of demeanor and
  credibility of counsel.Â  Id.Â  Often the demeanor of the challenged
  attorney will be the best and only evidence of discrimination, and evaluation
  of the attorneyâ€™s mind lies peculiarly within a trial judgeâ€™s province.Â  Shuler,
  at 615, 545 S.E.2d at 810 (citing Hernandez v. New York, 500 U.S. 352 (1991).Â  Therefore, those findings are given great deference and will not be set
  aside unless clearly erroneous.Â  Evins, at 416, 645 S.E.2d at 910.Â  
In my opinion, the
